repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Initial implementation for sharing C utility functions. The main goal of this PR is to introduce plumbing needed for sharing C utility functions. This PR currently shares:

* `__Pyx_Py3MetaclassPrepare`
* `__Pyx_Py3ClassCreate`
* `__Pyx_PyObject_CallMethod0`
* `__Pyx_PyObject_CallMethod1`

In subsequent PRs additional functions can be added - see #6963. Additional functions can require more adjustments in utility code and also in Cython code.

comment_data.body:
Continuing discussion in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6963#discussion_r2161926443

I have implemented as proposed but now I am thinking. Currently, in any case we support exporting/offloading C utilities having only function prototypes in `.proto` section. Hence does it make sense to have another section? We can just mark utility as exported and parse `.proto` section:

```c
/////////////// Py3ClassCreate.proto ///////////////
//@shared
static PyObject *__Pyx_Py3MetaclassPrepare(PyObject *metaclass, PyObject *bases, PyObject *name, PyObject *qualname,
                                           PyObject *mkw, PyObject *modname, PyObject *doc); /*proto*/
static PyObject *__Pyx_Py3ClassCreate(PyObject *metaclass, PyObject *name, PyObject *bases, PyObject *dict,
                                      PyObject *mkw, int calculate_metaclass, int allow_py2_metaclass); /*proto*/
```
But in this case I need to ensure that comments are allowed in the parsing though...
Maybe since moved to global, we can improve name not sure what the new name should be though. Any idea is welcome.

Maybe "get_utility_code_special_comment_matcher`?

It might be clearer as a `staticmethod` on UtilityCode? (In which case the name could be shortened to `get_special_comment_matcher`) but maybe there's some past discussion of this that I've missed that decided to make it global

```
[^)]
```

This forces C function pointers to be written as a typedef.

However - I think we should accept it for now and deal with that limitation if we hit it.

comment_data.body:
Personally, I don't think it's a bad thing to make it explicit what gets exported.

(Although I think handling C comments would actually be pretty easy as a pre-processing step).

```suggestion
    def parse_export_functions(cls, export_proto):
```

I think this reads slightly better

     is_cython_utility = False

+    type_matcher = re.compile(

@@ -27,6 +29,21 @@ def generate_tree(compsrc):
 
         return generate_tree
 
+    def generate_c_utilities(module_node):
+        UtilityCode = Code.UtilityCode
+        match_special = UtilityCode.get_special_comment_matcher('/')
+        for c_utility_file in [f for f in os.listdir(Code.get_utility_dir()) if f.endswith('.c')]:
+            all_lines = Code.read_utilities_hook(c_utility_file)
+            for line in all_lines:
+                m = match_special(line)
+                if m and m.group('name'):
+                    name = m.group('name')
+                    if mtype := UtilityCode.type_matcher(name):
+                        name, type = mtype.groups()
+                        if type == 'export':
+                            module_node.scope.use_utility_code(UtilityCode.load_cached(name, c_utility_file))
+        return module_node

@@ -452,6 +451,18 @@ class UtilityCodeBase(AbstractUtilityCode):
     is_cython_utility = False
     _utility_cache = {}
 
+    type_matcher = re.compile(
+        r'(.+)[.](proto(?:[.]\S+)?|impl|init|cleanup|module_state_decls|module_state_traverse|module_state_clear|export)$'
+    ).match
+
+
+    @staticmethod
+    def get_special_comment_matcher(comment):
+        return re.compile(
+            (r'^%(C)s{5,30}\s*(?P<name>(?:\w|\.)+)\s*%(C)s{5,30}|'
+             r'^%(C)s+@(?P<tag>\w+)\s*:\s*(?P<value>(?:\w|[.:])+)') %
+            {'C': comment}).match

+    @classmethod

+        for ret_type, func_name, func_params in re.findall(proto_regex, export_proto, re.VERBOSE):
+            shared_protos.append({

comment_data.body: Everything call related is usually intended to be inlined in one way or another. The two method call sections are not good candidates for moving out of the module.

comment_data.body:
I'm not sure if I understand the name `shared_utility_loaded` correctly. What has been loaded here?
Do you just mean `utility_code_is_shared`?

Or maybe, since the flag is apparently only relevant if we also have `self.shared_utility_functions`:
```suggestion
        has_shared_utility_code = bool(self.shared_utility_functions and output.module_node.scope.context.shared_utility_qualified_name)
```
That simplifies the conditions below and makes them clearer, I think.

comment_data.body: Can we please guard against silent failures to parse unexpected declarations by requiring that all non-space content must be parsed here? Rather than using `.findall()`, we could parse one declaration and then only ignore space characters up to the next one, making it an error if anything is left after parsing.

comment_data.body: Since this essentially short-circuits the whole method implementation, I suggest making the utility code sharing a separate method and call it right in the beginning, before even the `if self.requires:` condition above. It's not specific to the "proto" section where you put it, it's really an entirely separate case overall.

comment_data.body:
Rather than injecting new code layout parts into the file at random points, they should always exist in the `code_layout` list and just stay empty if they are unused.

I think all of the `__Pyx_ExportFunction()` calls, ~including the already existing ones,~ can go into a separate C function called by the module init function (maybe `__Pyx_ExportUtilityFunctions`) with a separate code layout part. The new shared functions can then just add code to that part.

The same applies to the function importing. Just add a C function (and layout section) for that as well, leave it empty if unused, fill it with function imports (and maybe also the shared module import) if used. Inside of such a function, you're free to use your own local variables and don't need to resort to allocating temps etc.

EDIT: The existing function export code already uses a separate function, so those for the utility functions should go into a new one, see above.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1556,6 +1600,9 @@ def initialize_main_c_code(self):
         code.putln("")
         code.putln("/* --- Runtime support code --- */")
 
+    def register_part(self, name, code):
+        self.parts[name] = code.insertion_point()

comment_data.body:
Ah, seeing this combination now helped me understand that the variable names intend to distinguish the two cases of using or being the shared module, right? That was totally not clear to me before. Then I suggest:
```suggestion
        using_shared_utility_module = bool(self.module_node.scope.context.shared_utility_qualified_name)
        in_shared_utility_module = bool(self.module_node.scope.context.options.shared_c_file_path)
```

But please move this entire code section out of `Code.py`. It seems a better fit as separate methods in `ModuleNode` for the "in" and "using" case, called before `finalize_main_c_code()`, rather than being a part of this method here. It doesn't have to do anything with the finalisation, it's really something that is part of the module's functionality.

         code.putln("")
 
+        shared_module_loaded = self.module_node.scope.context.shared_utility_qualified_name
+        shared_module_generated = self.module_node.scope.context.options.shared_c_file_path

comment_data.body: I actually meant the "export" section to also appear in the modules, before the "proto" section, to specifically avoid this redundancy between the two sections. Just move the exported declarations over from the proto section (instead of copying them here) and then remove the `/* proto */` marker (with or without spaces) as part of the preprocessing.
Can we separate out the memoryview specific tests? It seems an undesired side-effect to exclude the shared module tests just because memoryviews are not available for some reason.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,6 +36,7 @@ run[.]pyarray
 run[.]sequential_parallel
 run[.]special_methods_T561
 run[.]cythonscope
+run[.]shared_utility

comment_data.body: I think we can keep this as `match_type = self.match_section_title` to avoid redundant class attribute lookups below.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -500,12 +511,8 @@ def load_utilities_from_file(cls, path):
             comment = '/'
             strip_comments = partial(re.compile(r'^\s*//.*|/\*[^*]*\*/').sub, '')
             rstrip = partial(re.compile(r'\s+(\\?)$').sub, r'\1')
-        match_special = re.compile(
-            (r'^%(C)s{5,30}\s*(?P<name>(?:\w|\.)+)\s*%(C)s{5,30}|'
-             r'^%(C)s+@(?P<tag>\w+)\s*:\s*(?P<value>(?:\w|[.:])+)') %
-            {'C': comment}).match
-        match_type = re.compile(
-            r'(.+)[.](proto(?:[.]\S+)?|impl|init|cleanup|module_state_decls|module_state_traverse|module_state_clear)$').match

comment_data.body:
I don't think this is is possible because the contents of the shared module are fixed and include memoryviews. So they just don't work on early limited API

It's possible that later we might want some configurability of the shared module but that seems like a complication right now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,6 +36,7 @@ run[.]pyarray
 run[.]sequential_parallel
 run[.]special_methods_T561
 run[.]cythonscope
+run[.]shared_utility

comment_data.body:
> Everything call related is usually intended to be inlined in one way or another. 

But this function is not marked as `inline` hence it is not 100% true. Yes, I am aware that modern C compilers are able to determine and inline the function based on code analysis but still we are not sure. I mean if this function should be inline it should not be marked as `inline`. And if it is not marked so it can be moved to shared modules...

> The two method call sections are not good candidates for moving out of the module.

Hmm so it means that `__Pyx_PyObject_CallMethod0` should not be used as shared?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2385,6 +2393,10 @@ static PyObject *__Pyx_Object_VectorcallMethod_CallFromBuilder(PyObject *name, P
 }
 #endif
 
+/////////////// PyObjectCallMethod0.export ///////////////
+
+static PyObject* __Pyx_PyObject_CallMethod0(PyObject* obj, PyObject* method_name);
+

comment_data.body: I'm actually not sure why its implementation doesn't use `PyObject_VectorcallMethod()` but that might just be an oversight, it probably should. Functions this small really shouldn't need to go through a function call, let alone a function pointer. The C compiler should just inline the C-API function call here.

 }
 #endif
 
+/////////////// PyObjectCallMethod0.export ///////////////
+
+static PyObject* __Pyx_PyObject_CallMethod0(PyObject* obj, PyObject* method_name);
+

@@ -452,6 +451,19 @@ class UtilityCodeBase(AbstractUtilityCode):
     is_cython_utility = False
     _utility_cache = {}
 
+    match_section_title = re.compile(
+        r'(.+)[.](proto(?:[.]\S+)?|impl|init|cleanup|module_state_decls|module_state_traverse|module_state_clear|export)$'
+    ).match
+    @staticmethod
+    def get_special_comment_matcher(line_comment_char):
+        line_comment_char = '\#' if line_comment_char == '#' else line_comment_char
+        return re.compile((
+            # section title
+            r'^%(C)s{5,30}  \s*  (?P<name> (?:\w|\.)+ )  \s*  %(C)s{5,30} |'
+            # section tags and dependencies
+            r'^%(C)s+  @(?P<tag> \w+)  \s*  :  \s*  (?P<value> (?: \w|[.:] )+ )'
+        ) % {'C': line_comment_char}, re.VERBOSE).match

@@ -27,6 +29,21 @@ def generate_tree(compsrc):
 
         return generate_tree
 
+    def generate_c_utilities(module_node):
+        UtilityCode = Code.UtilityCode
+        match_special = UtilityCode.get_special_comment_matcher('/')
+        for c_utility_file in [f for f in os.listdir(Code.get_utility_dir()) if f.endswith('.c')]:
+            all_lines = Code.read_utilities_hook(c_utility_file)
+            for line in all_lines:
+                m = match_special(line)
+                if m and m.group('name'):
+                    name = m.group('name')
+                    if mtype := UtilityCode.match_section_title(name):
+                        name, type = mtype.groups()
+                        if type == 'export':
+                            module_node.scope.use_utility_code(UtilityCode.load_cached(name, c_utility_file))
+        return module_node

@@ -27,6 +29,22 @@ def generate_tree(compsrc):
 
         return generate_tree
 
+    def generate_c_utilities(module_node):
+        UtilityCode = Code.UtilityCode
+        match_special = UtilityCode.get_special_comment_matcher('/')
+        for c_utility_file in os.listdir(Code.get_utility_dir()):
+            if not c_utility_file.endswith('.c'):
+                continue
+            for line in Code.read_utilities_hook(c_utility_file):
+                if not (m := match_special(line)):
+                    continue
+                if not (section_title := UtilityCode.match_section_title(m.group('name'))):
+                    continue

@@ -27,6 +29,22 @@ def generate_tree(compsrc):
 
         return generate_tree
 
+    def generate_c_utilities(module_node):
+        UtilityCode = Code.UtilityCode
+        match_special = UtilityCode.get_special_comment_matcher('/')
+        for c_utility_file in os.listdir(Code.get_utility_dir()):
+            if not c_utility_file.endswith('.c'):
+                continue
+            for line in Code.read_utilities_hook(c_utility_file):
+                if not (m := match_special(line) and name := m.group('name')):

commit.message: Initial implementation of shared C utility code
Multiple functons can be shared now
Add new shared functions + fix import issue
Use ObjectHandling shared utility code + adjust unittests
Avoid Compilation warning when cimport function is not needed
Parse exported function proto instead of composing it from parameter
